poem:
**Closed Door Schedule**

Morning paper, coffee cooling,  
Hillary says cover‑up, Trump is "not expected to speak,"  
and in Geneva men in suits arrange chairs  
as if peace could be seated.

Four years since the invasion—  
time measured in minutes stamped GMT,  
in summits kicking off,  
in names that drift like smoke  
across a kitchen table.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Hillary Clinton accuses Trump administration of Epstein files cover-up – US politics live 2.15pm GMT My colleague, Jakub Krupa, is covering the latest developments out of Europe. He’s keeping an eye on the US brokered talks between Ukraine and Russia, as representatives continue to negotiate an end to the conflict. A reminder that it’s been almost four years since Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine. Jakub notes that the summit kicked off about an hour ago in Geneva. Related: France releases suspected Russian shadow fleet tanker after huge fine, as Ukraine peace talks begin – Europe live 1.17pm GMT Donald Trump is in Washington today. As of now, we’re not expected to hear from the president. He has a number of closed door meetings, but nothing open to the press according the official White House schedule. We’ll let you know if anything changes. 12.50pm GMT Senior Ukrainian and Russian officials are to meet this week in Switzerland for a third round of talks brokered by the Trump administration, days before the fourth anniversary of Moscow’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine. The two-day meeting, kicking off on Tuesday, is expected to mirror negotiations held earlier this month in Abu Dhabi, with representatives from Washington, Kyiv and Moscow in attendance. Despite renewed US efforts to revive diplomacy, hopes for any sudden breakthrough remain low, with Russia continuing to press maximalist demands on Ukraine. While the Abu Dhabi discussions were largely focused on military ceasefire proposals, the Kremlin spokesperson, Dmitry Peskov, said on Monday the". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
